bestBHT.bht: As Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, you are to show proper respect and obedience to your husbands. By doing good and not allowing fear to discourage you, you follow in the footsteps of Sarah. You need not be afraid of any sudden fear or be terrified by any threats from unbelieving husbands. Remember that you have become children of Abraham and Sarah by faith, and as such, you are to imitate their faith and obedience. Your obedience should not be driven by fear but by a courageous and intrepid spirit, uniting faith and obedience in your daily lives.

Henry Alford: as (e. g.) Sarah obeyed (the tense in the original indicates not so much the habit, as her whole course of obedience considered as a completed whole) Abraham, calling him lord."
if (i. e., as A.V. “as long as,” but better and clearer) ye do good, and are not afraid of any sudden fear."

Within the limits of propriety and decorum, the common usage is the rule. There is sin in singularity, both as ministering to pride in ourselves, and as giving offence to others and discommending our holy religion.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: ye have become": "children" of Abraham and Sara by faith, whereas ye were Gentile aliens from the covenant.
Act well, and be not thrown into sudden panic, as weak females are apt to be, by any opposition from without.
You need fear no man in doing what is right: not thrown into fluttering agitation by any sudden outbreak of temper on the part of your unbelieving husbands, while you do well.
Albert Barnes: Showing proper respect for all classes of persons in the various relations of life.
If ye do well, terrified by no threats of unbelieving husbands.
They were to do well; to be faithful to their husbands; to be firm in their principles; to adhere steadfastly to what was true and good, whatever trials they might pass through.
Marvin Vincent: Amazement [πτοησιν] . Rev., terror. Compare the kindred verb ptohqhte, be terrified, Luke 21:9; Luke 24:37; on which, see note. The word means a scare, or nervous excitement.
John Calvin: Willingly submit to the authority of your husbands, nor let fear prevent your obedience, as though your condition would be worse, were you to obey.
Let them not raise up commotions at home...they often make much of a little thing, and thus disturb themselves and the family.
Perform the duties of their calling with a courageous and intrepid spirit.
Philip Schaff: Possibly as the standard by which the holy women of old measured their wifely submission.
The terms in which she spoke of Abraham in relation to herself are instanced as the natural expression of the spirit of meek subordination which animated her.

The statement is not that these women are (as the R. V., the Vulgate, etc., render it) Sarah’s children, far less that they shall be such, as some paraphrase it, but that they became or were made such.
Archibald T. Robertson: If ye do well...and are not put in fear by any terror.
John Gill: the wife ought to take care of the family, to educate her children, to serve and minister to her husband in all things, 'calling him her own lord'; which is what we learn from the example of Sarah, who called Abraham her lord"
those are the children of Abraham, who walk in the steps of his faith... so such are the daughters of Sarah, the children of the free woman, who imitate her in faith and obedience

with fortitude and intrepidity of mind [they] continue in the discharge of their duty to God and men, and particularly to their husbands, following them, and obeying their lawful commands, as Sarah did in Egypt, and in Gerar, though she exposed herself to great danger
John Wesley: Whose children ye are — In a spiritual as well as natural sense, and entitled to the same inheritance."
While ye discharge your conjugal duties, not out of fear, but for conscience' sake."

bhtAttempts.bht: As Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, you are to show proper respect and obedience to your husbands. By doing good and not allowing fear to discourage you, you follow in the footsteps of Sarah. You need not be afraid of any sudden fear or be terrified by any threats from unbelieving husbands. Remember that you have become children of Abraham and Sarah by faith, and as such, you are to imitate their faith and obedience. Your obedience should not be driven by fear but by a courageous and intrepid spirit, uniting faith and obedience in your daily lives.

As Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, you are to show proper respect and obedience to your husbands. By doing good and not allowing fear to discourage you, you follow in the footsteps of Sarah. You need not be afraid of any sudden fear or be terrified by any threats from unbelieving husbands. Remember that you have become children of Abraham and Sarah by faith, and as such, you are to imitate their faith and obedience. Your obedience should not be driven by fear but by a courageous and intrepid spirit.

In your relationships with your husbands, it is important to demonstrate the same obedience and respect that Sarah showed to Abraham, calling him lord. By doing good and not succumbing to fear, you are following Sarah's example. Don't be afraid of sudden fear or threats from unbelieving husbands. Remember that as a result of your faith, you have become children of Abraham and Sarah. Your obedience should stem from a courageous and steadfast spirit, rather than from fear.

As Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, you are to show proper respect and obedience to your husbands. By doing good and not allowing fear to discourage you, you follow in the footsteps of Sarah. You need not be afraid of any sudden fear or be terrified by any threats from unbelieving husbands. Remember that you have become children of Abraham and Sarah by faith, and as such, you are to imitate their faith and obedience. Your obedience should not be driven by fear but by a courageous and intrepid spirit.

In your relationships, it is vital to display the same obedience and respect as Sarah did towards Abraham, addressing him as lord. By performing good deeds and not succumbing to fear, you emulate Sarah's actions. Do not let sudden fear or threats from unbelieving husbands alarm you. Remember that you have become children of Abraham and Sarah through faith, and therefore should imitate their faith and obedience. Let your obedience be rooted in courage and fearlessness rather than fear.
